Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2012 10:41AM yellowfarmhouse wrote: Hi Abby, I had a baby when I was 36 and most likely had breast cancer even then -- just too small to detect.  I was dx at age 39 ( almost 40).  I was also so scared when given dx of Her2  and Stage 3.  But, after lots of treatment, I'm here at age 47 ( in remission) .  Feel free to email anytime.  The ladies here have been amazing support system for me and so you're in the right place!  Best Regards, Wendy from WI
Posts.Title: I am so scared Abby20 kathleen1966

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2009 01:50PM yellowfarmhouse wrote: Dear Diane, HI.  You've been through some treatment already it sounds like.  I too had surgery and they didn't expect positive nodes.  I had 4/9 positive.  I asked my surgeon why some people have only a few taken and some have 29 or 30.  He told me that different pathologists count differently but that he felt that they count the larger nodes.  Basically he left me with the impression that they scoop out all that they find in the axilla.  Anyhow.... others may post but I think they'll leave the expander.  Some people even have radiation with an expander but maybe you won't need rads?   I had two tumors positive in same breast and the rest of my breast had lots of DCIS.  It didn't stage me any different or cause any different treatment for me however.  They just staged me by the largest tumor.  You have treatment ahead of you and I'll pray that you'll get through it quickly and feel good.   I'm 4.5 years out since diagnosis.  I was so scared at first and never thought I'd make it this far.  But the treatments out there do work and there are many gals here who have and are still fighting .The ladies here have helped me so much and I pray you'll find answers and comfort too. blessings Wendy
Posts.Title: What happens if in lymph system? stef58 Seabee

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2007 04:23AM yellowfarmhouse wrote: Hi.  I was diagnosed quickly too -- within 10 days I had diagnosis, scans, biopsy, mastectomy.  But, in your case, it seems like it might be worth a second opionion just so you feel sure.  I had multifocal tumors too -- but mine were grade 3 and I was HER 2+ and 4+ nodes so my cancer was more aggressive.  At this point it seems like big decisions that affect the rest of your life so it never hurts to get more input .  Best wishes, take care, Wendy
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed, things are moving FAST! lookingforward4more Shirlann

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2010 08:31PM yellowfarmhouse wrote: HI.  I had endometriosis problems for many years leading up to a hysterectomy at age 38.  My surgeon asked me if I knew if my mom had taken DES because he said the shape of my uterus suggested it.  I had lots of trouble getting pregnant but I do have 4 bio kids.  Anyhow... fast forward 2 short years later, ( after partial hysterectomy) I found two breast lumps.  Actually whole breast was full of IDC and DCIS.  So had bilateral mast, chemo , rads.  I haven't really had the courage to ask my mom more about it as don't want her to feel that something she took may have caused a problem.  But, anyhow, I'm going to have my 4 daughters watched and checked like crazy!  Thanks for posting! Wendy
Posts.Title: DES Expsoure and Increased Cancer Risk Ezscriiibe NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2008 04:38AM yellowfarmhouse wrote: HI. I had the same pathology as you.  It seems like your regular doctor wants you to get an appointment sooner for some reason.  I was told that even though I had grade 3 cancer ( fast growing) that a few weeks was not a big deal and that I should take all the time I needed to make decisions.  On the second question... I had mastectomy ( on both sides) and the recovery wasn't long at all.  I took a couple of weeks off work but maybe could have gone back sooner if I had a desk  job.   It wasn't  all that painful either.  Drains are a nuisance though.  Maybe someone else will post otherwise but all went well for me.  I didn't do immediate reconstruction though so that may change things.  I did that later.  I found that process more painful.  I hope and pray that you'll have excellent medical care and that you will be surrounded by caring people.  Come here anytime to post questions.  The ladies here were and still are my lifeline. blessings, Wendy

Posts.Title: Anyone out there with the Chek2 gene mutation??? MNTaylor80 kber

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 09:00PM yellowfarmhouse wrote: HI.  I had multifocal IDC.  Double mast and then chemo.  Then rads.  I had 4 positive nodes removed.  So, because I had surgery before chemo, I think that is why they prescribed radiation to me.  They based it on the fact that I had 4 nodes positive.  Whereas yours ended up being negative.  I always thought that they were able to tell if nodes used to have cancer -- dead cancer cells or something like that?  Anyhow... I don't really know if chemo or rads helped or Herceptin or the Arimidex or the cancer vaccine trial.  But , almost 5 years out.  My good friend had 6 cm and adjuvant Chemo first and complete response and then had rads ( no Herceptin as Her2 neg) and she is also almost 5 years out.  Hope this helps, Wendy

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 07:51AM yellowfarmhouse wrote: Hi. Welcome to the boards... it's not a place where we wanted to be but the ladies here are awesome and so encouraging.  They held my hand through challenging times and always were able to give perspective and comfort.  I too am a Christian and it was hard to face that I'd have to go through all this.  I was so scared... my kids were little.... we were in a financial crunch.... insurance issues.... and each day it seemed like the docs gave more bad news..... then the hard treatments...  I prayed and thousands prayed for me.... over time, I got through the treatments and the news started to get better.  I had moments where I raged with anger, felt very sad, had anxiety  but also in the midst of it peace and growth.  I was a person who had a long way to go ( and still do) with simple trust.  But God holds in the palm of his hand.... Jer. 29:11 .. it's been 4.5 years... I know my future is still uncertain and there may be more scary times ahead... but a day at a time... please private message or post anytime... blessings, Wendy

It is hard when you have young kids.  I have five and my youngest two were 3 and 4 at the time.  Hang in there.  Chemo was rough for me too.  Actually AC was horrible but taxol and Herceptin were not as bad.  Come anytime with questions.  The ladies here were so wonderful ( and still are) for me... made lots of good friends -- I still come here almost every day.  blessings, Wendy--- private message also anytime.....

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 05:23AM yellowfarmhouse wrote: Hello to another Wendy, I was dx when I turned 40 almost 5 years ago.  I too had no family hx.  The first few weeks were downright scary, I had so much panic, anxiety, emotions.... and then such big decisions to make on top of it.  I did lots of internet research, read books from library etc.... this website really helped me the most.  I learned more here than from my oncologist.  It does change one's life dramatically.  I went from abnormally healthy to sick in one fell swoop.  Please know that we're all here pulling for ya. Come here anytime to ask questions.... Blessings, Wendy

Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2009 10:26PM yellowfarmhouse wrote: Dear Pam and all the newly diagnosed.... I remember well the sheer terror and shock and fear and yet strength and love from others I felt in those first few weeks.  It was surreal-- I remember the night  my doctor called with the news and having to gather our five young children to tell them.  My hubby was at work and I had to call him .   The children handled it all pretty well actually, it seemed good to give them at least basic info as they knew something was wrong anyway.  We gathered in a circle and we prayed and I remember praying that God would give me words to say and He did.  We talked about how we are like "Knights" and how we would all have to be brave and fight the good fight.  My son got his wooden sword and we all "knighted " each other and cried.  Four years have passed.  It has been a wild ride and a crazy journey but I have learned much and though I can never say I'm really glad it happened, I have grown and learned how a lot .  Please let those around you help whenever possible, be kind to yourself .  The emotions run strong, my husband was wonderful in some ways but we were both scared and too afraid to even let each other know how much.  Chemo was not fun but it was doable.  One day and one step at a time.  There were many unknowns and obstacles and the future was uncertain and still is.  I just got home from my ladies group tonight and these gals walked though the journey with me and have seen my worst fears, anger, and they loved my through it.  I pray that you can be surrounded by a wonderful team.  Some advice that I have is to reseach and talk to others -- the gals here helped me immensely in my decision making. I read tons of posts  and asked lots of questions.  I was surprised at how my attitudes and ideas changed along the way.  Be flexible , there are many decisions right away but some things can be decided later on.  You are all in my thoughts and prayers, dear sisters.  I don't post as often anymore but I come and read posts and think of you all. We're all in this together.  Take care and if you have any questions please feel free to send a message.  Blessings, Wendy dx 2.4.05 stage 3A, 4+ nodes IDC,multifocal , AC+T with Herceptin dose dense, rads, cancer vaccine trial in Seattle, ER/PR+,Her2+.  Age 44 now with five kids under 15 who I have thankfully seen grow four years older!!!
Posts.Title: I was just diagnosed yesterday and am scared aris desdemona222b

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2009 05:07AM yellowfarmhouse wrote: HI.  I had a very similar diagnosis.  They didn't think I'd had positive nodes.  But after surgery they found 4/9.  So then my options changed.   Prior to BC, I led a very healthy lifestyle and had no risk factors.  Had some prior use of BC pills but other than that nothing.  I just turned 40, now I'm 4 years post and 44 years old.  I took chemo, rads, bilateral,  Herceptin and Arimidex.  I now try to eat even healthier and more organic and less milk and meat and get more sunshine and take some supplements.  It's really a hard time and hard decisions and I wish you the best.   Looking  back, I think that chemo seemed like nuclear war and Herceptin seemed like a silver bullet.  Not sure what worked but I'm here today .   wendy
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2015 09:02PM yellowfarmhouse wrote: I will also be a 10 year survivor Feb 2015.  My dx was IDC.  I had 2 lumps and 4/9 positive nodes.  ER 3+, PR 1+ and HER 2 3+. Had bilateral mastectomy, dose dense AC + T followed by a year of Herceptin and then vaccine clinical trial.  Recently dx with CHEK 2 genetic mutation.  There is hope..... Wendy
Posts.Title: Stage III Cancer Survivors .... 10+ Years and Out AlwaysHope karen1956

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2009 04:19AM yellowfarmhouse wrote: Dear Melanie, My OB told me for sure I had cancer just from mammo and ultrasound results too.  I had it in two spots in same breast.  I'm a mom of 5.  My youngest was 3 at the time -- but now she is 8!  It's a scary time!  So much info to absorb and many decisions to make.  I remember having to decide stuff in a time when I could barely think.  And so many people kept coming over to the house.  I actually had to take some time to get away to think and pray. I couldn't keep up my brave front for the kids so it helped to go for long walks.  My mind kept racing and I had so much anxiety.  So, I wore headphones and blasted inspirational music in my ears while waiting during the  many appointments.  And I spent time on this website learning from all the super amazing ladies here.  I was considered stage 2 at the time so had surgery and then started chemo and then had radiation.   But, I guess things changed in treatment so maybe if I was diagnosed now, they may have shrunk the tumors first with chemo and then had surgery.   I had two tumors of 2 cm or so each and whole breast full of DCIS so I didn't actually have a choice about lumpectomy or mastectomy.  But, I have friends who had have each .  I chose bilateral mastectomy .  My other breast was totally clear so I could have kept it.  It's really an individual decision.  There are many terms to learn.... but hopefully you'll have awesome doctors.  And the American Cancer society representative was really helpful to me too when I had questions.  And this website. take good care,blessings and prayers, Wendy

Posts.Content: May 16, 2010 10:37PM yellowfarmhouse wrote: HI.  The same thing happened to me.  I got a call from my OBgyn who said the by the looks of mammo and U/S that it was cancer.  However, it is very true that the biopsy is the only way they really know for sure.  The good thing was that they took it out completely during the biopsy so I woke up feeling good about that.  My surgeon really got me through the process quickly and I was thankful for that.  I did all the treatments and now it is 5.5 years later.  I'll be thinking of ya tomorrow.  Wendy

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 11:00AM yellowfarmhouse wrote: Dear Kendall, wow, you've been through a lot already.  it's so frustrating waiting for appointments and waiting for info to trickle in.  I was blessed to have a grandfatherly surgeon who went to bat for me and made calls... I overheard him saying.... " just get us a surgery date for tomorrow."   It scared the crap out of me because it made me feel like I was really in bad shape but at least he shortened the time I had to wait.  He told me that his own daughter had breast cancer at age 33 ( she's fine now) .  I was  39 at diagnosis.  It was a scary time... I'm praying that all this is caught really early for ya ... in my case... they didn't want to do mammo earlier than 40 as I had no family history... if I had it done at maybe 35 or 36 would have been much earlier stage... but that's water under the bridge.... I pray you have awesome docs and great care and good support... speedy surgery and recovery.... and hopefully no chemo... I had to do that and rads... not fun but doable.  prayers and blessings, Wendy

Posts.Title: Stephanie is an Angel 2timer Britt

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 05:18PM yellowfarmhouse wrote: Thanks for sharing your story. Those first days were so scary and awful.  BC is an awful disease and we all hope and pray that there can be better treatments. On my way home from work today, I passed by the cancer center where I was treated and thought about what the date is today.  It's been 6 years.  6 years ago I never thought that I'd be alive much less working a new job teaching physical therapy and never dreamed that I wouldn't think about cancer every minute of the day.  I had a chance to share with my students about my diagnosis to increase awareness and help them be more informed as they treat people who have or are dealing with cancer.  I am also thankful to have had 6 more years as a mama.  My kids were 2-11 and are now 10-17.When I hear people lament the teen years, I just smile inside and realize that no matter how hard it is being a parent, it's a gift to be alive and able to weather the storms of growing up with them. BC.org has been an enormous blessing to me too.  Met so many wonderful friends and did treatment together.  The ladies here have always been so encouraging and yet willing to tell me " like it is."     May you and all our wonderful sisters here have many more healthy days, years, decades. Karen , best wishes to you and your family.   Blessings, Wendy

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2007 04:54PM yellowfarmhouse wrote: Hi!  I remember running out of steam at about the 1.5 to 2 year mark.  I charged through treatment and I kept running too-- did the Susan Komen 5 k when I finished rads.  Then, I did reconstruction and somewhere along the line I got tired and discouraged and mentally drained.  I wish I had the answer to how to get though it... I guess I came on BC.org and gained encouragement often and I took a break from some obligations and I also attended a breast cancer recovery retreat here in Wisconsin.  I think the retreat helped so much as I spent 4 days with other survivors on an island and we did stuff like throw stones in Lake Superior to cast away some of our fears.  I wish I could say every day has been wonderful since then but I'd be lying.  But, now three years after diagnosis I can tell that my life is changing and I'm moving on a little bit more.  We're thinking of moving-- it's not something I would have even considered a year ago.  I'll pray for you and your family.  Life is so hard especially with the added things of illnesses in our families besides us having had breast cancer.  I pray that you'll have some time to relax and regroup and for joy and peace during the holiday season.  blessings, Wendy

Posts.Title: OMG Brain Mets for me BJW Maya1

Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2008 01:21AM yellowfarmhouse wrote: Hi again, I think it's called histoplasmosis.  Common where there is bird droppings.  So, that seems like anyone who spends much time in nature.  I had cleaned out our chicken coop a couple of times.  I guess our lungs wall off the offending spore and then form calcium deposits.  I had  another scare last summer.  I developed bumps on the skin of my reconstructed breast.  Turns out those were scars from poison ivy but it took 1500.00 worth of path tests to figure it out.  I hate the waiting when stuff like that happens.  And all the medical people treat me like it's probably going to turn out to be cancer!!!  GRR!!!!  I keep having to repeat the mantra, when you hear hoofbeats, think horses, not zebras.  But, it's so hard to do when we turned out to have breast cancer against all odds.  In any case, it's good they watch us close but I wish that we didn't have to face these awful scares! blessings to ya, hope you get good B9 results soon, prayers, Wendy
Posts.Title: Spot on my lung........... Naomi Naomi

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2009 11:07AM yellowfarmhouse wrote: HI.  just wanted to send some cyber hugs your way.  you've been through so much.  I'm 44 years old and a 4.5 year survivor.  You are in the scary time right now.  It seemed to get a bit better for me after I and docs figured out treatment plan because then I had a goals to shoot for and treatment to go to.  I cried a lot , had so many people praying..... people were ( and are ) so wonderful .  This board is an awesome place to be.  Got me through many scares.  Praying for you to have a good day.  blessings, Wendy
Posts.Title: Need to Talk GmaToni GmaToni

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2008 09:27AM yellowfarmhouse wrote: Dear Jenni,  So sorry you have to go through this.  I had insurance but had high deductable.  What helped me is that the clinic/hospital itself had a program called " Community Care" for people such as us.  I applied and they granted me about 9000.00.  I think that many if not most hospitals have a  charitable branch for such cases.  Inquire with social services.  But in any case, proceed with the recommended treatment.  God is indeed faithful and provided for us every step of the way.  I remember having trouble sleeping during that early diagnosis time.  One minute I felt up and encouraged and brave and the next I was very anxious.  It's a scary time.  4 years ago I thought that I could never survive it all but here I am.  Hang in there and feel free to  private message anytime!!! blessings, Wendy

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2010 08:38PM yellowfarmhouse wrote: HI.  I'm not a nurse but I work with and greatly respect nurses.  I'm a physical therapist and I'm sorry to hear of your pain.  After having BC 5 years ago, I've struggled with lifting patients like I used to due to back pain.  I've been a PT for 22 years.  So, now I'm moving into the field of PT education.  I've worked with back patients for many years.... good things to work on are posture, stretches and "core " exercises. Use of cold packs is helpful... I hesitate to use ultrasound on patients who have have breast cancer--- electrical stim should be OK... but I tend to be more conservative and really exercise should help us the most anyway.  Feel free to PM me anytime, blessings, Wendy

Posts.Title: Stage III rads reconstruction question ksingh0 Hope_M

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2010 09:19PM yellowfarmhouse wrote: HI.  You had a really similar diagnosis as me.  I had Neulasta-- was pretty fit at the time and was 40 years old.  They decided that  I didn't need as big of a dose and cut it slightly at the end as my bones ached so much.  But, on the other hand, I didn't come down with infections or anything while in chemo.  So, who knows?  Wishing you the very best, Wendy
Posts.Title: Is Neulasta Helpful? TonLee TonLee

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2010 06:57PM yellowfarmhouse wrote: HI. I had AC x 4 and then taxol with Herceptin x 4 and then Herceptin weekly x 8 and then Herceptin every three weeks until one year.  I had radiation after finished Taxol.  I started my chemo in March during flu season and my five kids were all young... I had one cold that happened and my fever shot up to 104 and had a cough so they put me on antiobiotic for a few days but was otherwise spared any serious infection.  I guess there is no way to predict.  I did have a lot of pain /aching which they said could be attributed to Neulasta -- hard to walk but I managed to walk about a mile every day anyway.  ( But normally had been a person who walked or ran 3-5 miles per day.)  Chemo had it's own SE like horrible mouth sores and the nausea-- they told me that they didn't think I'd need much medicine for nausea( I have no idea why they predicted that) but I got really sick with first treatment.  I kind of think that they can't predict things like that... so, I'd make sure they they give you lots of anti nausea stuff for sure. Not sure about the Neulasta thing but I've heard statistics on how many women end up hospitalized at least once while in chemo-- can't remember the numbers but it's worth looking up.  I just hope the very best for you!  Take care, Wendy
Posts.Title: Is Neulasta Helpful? TonLee TonLee
